KfnTEJvRMKgerCA-ypXEgQ.text: We went for NYE dinner and everything about the experience was subpar.  This was our second time dining here and will absolutely be our last.  We had the 4 course meal along with the wine pairing.  Our wine came out way before our meal and each course was cold and overly salted.  The wait staff was inexperienced and inattentive.  They served us the wrong cocktail to start off, placed the wrong meal in front of us, and the food runners that were serving the food could not explain the dish being served.  For two people the price was $500 and with the staff knowing we did not enjoy the experience they did not do anything to make it right (except give us a $50 gift card to come back which we will be giving away).   Save yourself the money and frustration and take your business and hungry tummies anywhere but here.

GJ4bAVdG9FBnxUJvy7En1g.text: My boyfriend and I went do our anniversary and could not have been more pleased. The food was DELICIOUS, elegant, and the ambiance was great. Our waiter, Jason clearly described all of the amazing food we ate including where it came from. We did the 6 course tasting and had one of the best, if not the best, meals of our lives.   They started us with delicious bread and butter and olive oil before the course started. The chef's board was comprised of meat, cheese, and fruit and was heavenly. The Pistachio Soup might have been my favorite course with pork belly croutons and goat cheese mousse. Yum!! Next was a beet salad that tasted so fresh followed by a pasta course. The pasta and sauce was like and delicious. Our entrees came next. I had the trout and my boyfriend had the duck. The trout had the most delicious salty skin and my mouth is watering just thinking about it! We finished with dessert and I was sadly too full to eat a ton. We shared the bread pudding and the hazelnut chocolate pie. So good!   The entire meal took about 2.5 hours, and we had a a romantic experience. If you're looking to get in and out, this isn't the place because it is a truly a dining experience. Highly recommended!

Z5p0iw11zxpoZS1pKIYmXA.text: This was a wonderful birthday experience.   My birthday falls just after Valentine's Day, so they were still serving the 4 course fixed Valentine's menu which was perfect  for us, but some other diners seemed surprised by this.  We started with a couple delicious and unique cocktails at the bar before moving on to our table.  We requested to sit inside since it was a bit chilly and I am not a huge fan of outdoor dining anyway.  We were seated by a window on the "porch", which alowed a great view without actually being outside.   It was however still a bit chilly  I would have appreciated a space heater or something.  The service was friendly, knowledgeable, and efficient without being overbearing.  Dinner was fabulous.   From the pistachio soup, gnocchi, and salad to the perfectly cooked duck breast to the breads, and delicious bread pudding dessert, we enjoyed every bite.  They did offer a wine pairing option, but we chose to get a bottle from their excellent wine list which had a great variety of varietals and price points.  There  were only a few very picky things that could have made it better.  First, on Open table we were only able to get a reservation at 5:45 which was a bit early for us.  We were there until after 8 and the place was never even close to being full, so not sure why we couldn't have come later.  Second, while the duck was cooked perfectly and delicious, it was a bit on the cool side.  Not sure if this was intentional or not but my husband and I both agreed it could have been a tad warmer.  Lastly we were fortunate to catch that 20% gratuity had automatically been added to the check.  We didn't see anywhere on the menu that this would happen and the server didn't mention it either.  Now, we would have tipped at least this anyway, but we nearly tipped double that before we noticed the addition.   This place is pricy, so that would have been an expensive mistake!  Other than these small things, it was a magical experience, and we look forward to going again  for a special occasion.

1_WCZDIq6LgF9N5eapT7Vw.text: What an experience. I was treated to this fine dinner on my birthday and I enjoyed every moment of it. I definitely recommend the 6 course dinner. This was my first time having a dinner of this nature and I loved every moment of it. The courses were full of flavors my pallet has never tasted before. Service was great..our server explained every Ingredient for each course that came out.   We sat outside which made for a very romantic dinner as the sun set and our table was slowly lit with a rope of hanging lights and a candle. Each course came out with enough time to enjoy the previous, a glass of wine, and some great conversation in between.   Definitely recommend the bread pudding for desert!!

GxG1jN5ZY9x6K4cp79WLNQ.text: Beautiful place overall, located at the farm and when you arrive it can look a little different but the moment you spot this place, the feeling there after is not short of magical. We got a great server, She was so good and everyone made sure we had a great time. So full marks on their service, they made sure they gave us our own time and they were super helpful with all the information without being intrusive.  The bread with the butter was like the most amazing thing ever. The squash soup with goat cheese tasted so good. I actually like to have small quantities on each of my courses so it worked perfect for me as I would want to not feel full after having such a good experience.   I got a bread pudding as a dessert and that was really good too.

photos.caption: Photo of Quiessence At The Farm - Phoenix, AZ, United States
Photo of Quiessence At The Farm - Phoenix, AZ, United States. Perfect setting and lights

HZBsFiDteXdFttuBf5fbNQ.text: It is unfortunate that the food at Quiessence is decent because it is undercut by the horrible dinner service.   Came for the 5 course tasting on NYE, each course took about an hour to be served, with no apologies from management or the servers. I've eaten at fine dining restaurants all over the world, and I know that the experience is not to be rushed. However, courses are usually well-timed, and the servers don't ignore their tables to avoid confrontation.   The front of the house staff carried on as though nothing was wrong. All the diners were visibly upset and the entire night was mismanaged. My boyfriend finally asked our server what was going on with the food and that was the first time the problem was acknowledged. We talked to the manager who was in denial about the state of the evening, and made no apologies until we expressed our dissatisfaction. If the servers were more cognizant   My boyfriend asked for half of our meal off, and his request was granted. Thank goodness he did, because although we received a discount the meal still cost upwards of $300. I sincerely hope the other diners had the sense of doing the same thing. In addition, this restaurant had the audacity to threaten a $50/person 48hr cancellation fee, for a dinner service that they could not handle.   Long story short, I could not recommend this place less. The food was good but not enough to make up for the clueless management and staff.

6l0RozG9XtH52DJB_8nozQ.text: Amazing dining experience with a great service and ambience. We did the 5 course meal. Liked the wine tasting pairings with food. Me being a vegetarian I loved the food and flavors. Although others thought that food portion should be increased for the non vegetarian options.

photos.caption: Photo of Quiessence At The Farm - Phoenix, AZ, United States

eTqY1ZWg7aiTSn6VBH-CPw.text: Very disappointing!  High prices, slow service, terrible food, skimpy portions. Quiessence is on my DGB (DON'T GO BACK) list. Also, they charge five dollars to split a salad - which adds insult to injury since it was the worst salad I have ever had.

9Paq8QVdZsvOe5nsEuFNwQ.text: Whatever you think the world is withholding from you, you are withholding from the world. Here at Quiessence, the incredibly creative farm-to-table concept feeds you their love straight from the garden to your soul. This lovely quaint romantic spot competes right up there with your 5-star steakhouses. The uniqueness of the menu changes year round so I happen to visit during Restaurant Week. The menu was exquisite from the butternut squash soup to the filet mignon, to the celebratory cannoli and bread pudding. Service is efficient without the sacrifice of being personable and friendly. I adore moonlights and would have dined under the pecan trees but it was rather hot. So if you dine here in the later fall months, I highly recommend it. You will love it very much...fall quickly, love fully, and most importantly love naturally - the food, the atmosphere and hopefully your company.

photos.caption: Photo of Quiessence At The Farm - Phoenix, AZ, United States. I think my soulmate is food.

6AJb7pvaxRXRBbOqMecPlA.text: Quiessence is a quirky place- located in a very romantic setting on an old pecan farm in South Phoenix. Lots of little lights and we sat by a fireplace. The restaurant seems to meander throughout many rooms and areas - we were told there was a party of 40 people somewhere in a private room - although we never saw or heard from them. The area we sat in was small and had only a few tables. So it was (as the name suggests) an intimate, peaceful experience.   Bottom line: the food was not memorable. There is a story attached to everything, as told by the wait staff, from the name of the place to the garden to the daily-changing menu, Arizona wines, etc. The prices are not to be sneezed at - we had a choice of 3 entrees that evening and they were each above $40. They suggest you order 2 or 3 courses to get 'the full experience' - we tried a parmesan soup, carpaccio appetizer and an entree. After all the talk and fanfare about freshness, and the warning on the menu that everything takes TIME (which it does: we sat at 7:15, got our drinks at about 7:45 and first food arrived at 8:45 - which is a long time!), the food was truly blase. I had a puree of some sort (about 2 tblspoons) that was totally without flavor - the fish was not remarkable in texture or flavor, etc. The pork was 'ok' - but a little tough. The carpaccio was a little salty - you get the idea. We skipped dessert because it was after 10pm by the time we finished eating and we didn't dare order anything else for fear we'd be asleep by the time it came. Also, I literally left hungry - about 2.5 ounces of fish with 2 peapods on top and the aforementioned puree. Soup and apps were similar - tiny portions served with much aplomb with a LOT of empty time left in between. If the food had been really good, it would have been well worth it all. But it just wasn't!

BBhMYUQdK7WB7yIMwLqgyg.text: On a trip where I ate at some very nice and upmarket restaurants, I looked back at my notes on Quiessence and found it hard to decide on its Yelp star rating. The quality of the food almost took it down to 3 stars but in the end, their attempt to be really interested and concerned about the provenance of their produce raised it to 4 stars. I felt that I could really taste the difference with the quality of the ingredients used.  The restaurant itself has a really rural feel to it despite being minutes from metropolitan Phoenix. The long driveway off the main road seems like a step into another world and the long walk from the car park to the low rise restaurant adds to the distinct impression that you're in the country. The interesting history of the restaurant and its associated projects on the grounds are explained in the menu. There is a changing daily menu and the use of fresh local produce is commendable.  Unfortunately, for me personally, it just all felt a little sterile and there wasn't much atmosphere in the place. Unlike some over-posh city establishments, I had expected more of a buzz and hubbub in this quaint restaurant but it was almost the opposite. The staff were efficient enough but lacked the True warmth of natural hosts. There was also the amusing view of them bringing in all the dishes from the kitchen which must have been in another building as they were carrying plates in from outside. This became especially interesting when it started raining.  I started with a board of charcuterie and cheese, which was almost the best course as you could taste the top class ingredients in their pure form. I was interested to taste a pluot for the first time, which was a cross between a plum and an apricot.  The next course of squash salad was average and not very exciting.  Perhaps the worst dish of the evening was cheese pasta with sausage that just had the wrong balance of ingredients. Too heavy for my liking.  However, the next course of steelhead with heirloom tomatoes was much better with perfectly cooked fish accompanied by some super sweet mis-shapen (yay!) tomatoes.  Unfortunately, this was followed by braised lamb that had unfortunately been over-seasoned.  The most spectacular course of the evening was the amazing dessert board. There was melon carpaccio with strawberry, goat's cheesecake, lemon cream, crumb cake, a cookie and truffles.  It's a real shame as I had really wanted to like Quiessence before I dined there but the overwhelming feeling as I left was that it could have been so much better.

pM1rLdYq5vGIi5hd0Ktvgg.text: Love this place! Great Food, Great Experience! Not for people who are picky eaters but great for Foodies! Only complaint is the price but I'll still go back!

W-vpeGq5CGiwgDoDK1F9GA.text: I worked at Quiessence for a short time so I know it well. I am friends with the GM, Dustin, as well as the Chef, Greg LePrad. The place is a cultural gem in Phoenix, and is the ultimate place to take Out-of-Towners to show them that Phoenix is not all strip mall dives and fast food chains.  Quiessence follows the "Slow Food" way as a philosophy and Greg and Dustin utilize the local produce from Maya's Farm to create delicious and simple rustic new American fare. Do not expect seeing Scottsdale waifs with big racks drinking red bull  and vodka here. The only chicks your going to see are baby Guineafowl scratching for bugs outside your urban farm window. This place is organic, natural, and relaxed.  Chef - Icon, Alain Ducasse wrote in his 2000 book, Harvesting Excellence, he wrote that the Farm at South Mountain as "Eden-like."  Adam...Eve...return to the garden as the Guineahen will keep the serpent at bay.

p_6cxFTonzq9O0i762C-KA.text: I am being kind when I describe this place as " a huge disappointment "  I have experienced this place three times in the last twelve months and have never been impressed by the food, service, or the ambiance. It's in a great location but is run as if it were a carnival ride. My server was slow and practically unavailable all evening. Each time we needed her she seemed to not see, or ignore my attempts to catch her attention. We were served entrees with no silverware long enough that our food got cold. Once we tasted the food I thought it had no more exotic flavor than our local "filbertos". The price we paid for our meal was quite high. It certainly wasn't worth it.

CGYHG8XqPfl7ijrlbtlZMA.text: The bar is set quite high and nearly attained...  Quiessence is one of my favorite restaurants in the valley.  There is much to enjoy and highly recommend this little gem (also recommend their lower key sister restaurants also at the farm).  High marks are earned for a remarkably creative menu and lovely space.  My partner and I tend to choose Quiessence for a celebratory meal and usually choose the tasting menu which when ordered for two allows one to taste most everything on the menu.  After living in Europe and traveling to far corners of the globe, I am admittedly something of a food snob.  My bias belief is that the higher a restaurant attains the less forgiveness for error.   Our rating for the 12 plates we tasted on Saturday, 9 would earn 10 out of 10, 2 would rate at 8 and one a 3.  I would gladly concede that the 8's where of the same creativeness as the 10's and perhaps not quite to our taste preference.  The 3 rating was surprising and keeps me from placing Quiescence on my global list of favorites.  The 3 in this case was the swordfish.  'Slightly' salty would be an understatement.  Whether this was 'as planned' or a very salty faux pas is hard to know.  We did suggest to our server that she may want to mention this to the Chef; whether she did and whether there was an answer we don't know.   Very noteworthy were the Salmon, Meat Balls, Gnocchi and Eggplant Soup. I am not a fan of noisy, over decorating venues and for us Quiessence is spot on.  Pleasant music is played at a volume that compliments the experience and allows for great conversation.  Decor that is subtle and doesn't over power.  One more suggestion that may be more of a personal preference is the lack of personality and sincerity of the service staff.  Service is always attentive and pleasant, but have never felt that the servers allow any of their personality to become part of the experience.  Perhaps we are in the minority and there are more that prefer a less personal service.

1gbvn9SAm2RYY2uN-GBkmg.text: We waited three years to try Quiessence .  Our first visit took place in early September to celebrate our 7 year wedding anniversary.  The previous year we celebrated at the celebrated 5-star restaurant "Marie Elaine's" at the Phoenician (which I think has since closed and turned into a different kind of restaurant).   It is to this that I'm comparing the experience.  The housing is small and intimate and even so, I didn't feel crowded. (I'm imagining folks who have read my other reviews rolling their eyes and saying "yes yes, we know you have space "issues.")  Here's what I loved best about the place: The food was wonderfully normal yet interesting (read: unpretentious -- no venison stew cooked over leaks and served in a copper pan.) The wait staff was knowledgeable and friendly (read: they weren't in tuxedo's with attitudes); and the atmosphere was relaxed (read: There was a live blues guitarist - no elevator music; you can dress up or down; and the food was well timed and not rushed).  I've heard that people complain that Quiessence is too expensive for the experience.  I say PHOOEY!   The food is fresh and organic.  The food selection is interesting and unique.  And the experience is special (read: NOT Scottsdale).     This place is off the beaten path and I'm sorry we waited three years to experience it.  Mea Culpa, mea culpa, mea maxima culpa.

-3nSMagUbJKEaGtegNDIcQ.text: So I have never written for yelp but I wanted to warn about the experience.  After spending over 500$ on dinner I cant think of a worse way to spend the money.   The Atmosphere lovely but the service, wine pairing and farmers feast felt like a scam.  For 45/person for wine pairings I would have expected fabulous picks (not a rose/syrah blend that tasted at best like bad sangria... more like hawaiian punch) and more than a thimbleful in each flight.  The Beef shoulder was overcooked and the spinach greens tasted like canned greens but with salt.  I will spare you the rest of the details but I have eaten at more than a few "high end" restaurants in my day and this one take first place at the worst.

-lSbDrWoWaDEzdokbU6-EQ.text: If you've been reading some of the more negative reviews about Quiessence let me explain some things.  For starters the restaurant is in the middle of a working farm, so the driveway is gravel and the grounds are covered in wood chips.  My wife and I rather enjoyed that, if it's something that's going to wreck your evening then don't come.  The dining area is somewhat cosy, if you're looking for a cavernous area full of shadowy corners this is not it.  Which is not to say you can't have a romantic meal, you just have to be willing to be near your fellow man.  The food was absolutely fantastic, and the wine pairings were superb.  The staff was friendly, knowledgeable, and prompt when we needed something.  Here's another point, dinner takes a while, if you're looking to shovel food down your maw and bolt then you're in the wrong restaurant. Courses are served in a laid back fashion, with plenty of time to look deeply into each others eyes and enjoy your wine.    So if you're looking for a nice dinner, in a quaint environment, with a wonderful service staff then Quiessence will suit you just fine.

BhT7Nnd9xITvT5a5hL3LHA.text: We went last night for a special tasting dinner, and it was a disappointment.  The service was poor (the wait staff did not seem to be well-trained); the individual dishes served were generally good, certainly fresh, but there was insufficient thought given to what went with what.  In all other restaurants we have ever been in, a tasting dinner has been served in small dishes so that everyone can share.  At Quiessence, they were served on normal dishes, but only one of each for the two of us.  Very awkward -- for example, how do you share a bowl of soup without it getting cold for one person or the other?  The main dishes were both pasta and meat dishes, but they were so different that it was a jarring taste experience to have a bit of one followed by a completely unrelated taste of another.

hUB-m8JzAm1GeHXiY6hliQ.text: (unfinished post) My husband and I went to Quiessence Restaurant for the first and, sadly, last time since it was the last night of service in its current iteration with Chef & Restaurateur Gregory LaPrad, Executive Chef Anthony Andiario, and Sous Chef Stevan Kosanovich. The entrance and atmosphere was rustic, ringing True of its location on a farm - Farm at South Mountain. Once welcomed and seated, we were impressed by the intimate ambiance and the impeccable service. Wine list was extensive, and the Farmhouse Cocktails I selected - Gin Giardino - was excellent. We ordered the Tasting Menu since it seemed to be the only option we had. The seven course were from heavenly to good --- consistently above average. Too numerous to count and comment on the offerings; just enjoying the pleasurable ride. Quiessence will be missed!

2k2k1cfMWC4Ujh-IWXkERA.text: POTENTIAL VALENTINES DAY DINERS BEWARE. I made a reservation at this restaurant on the 19 of January for Valentines Day dinner with my girlfriend. I received a confirmation e-mail saying that everything was all set and my reservation was good. Today I received a call from the restaurant saying that my reservation would be canceled unless I gave my credit card information over the phone. I didn't feel comfortable doing so and now my reservation is cancelled 2 weeks away from Valentines Day. I'm in the military and my girlfriend is from my home state. I get to see her maybe once every couple months. I just wanted to go somewhere she'd really like, now I'm kind of SOL. Very frustrated...

EpNlUG_7olzrgACFm9oDCQ.text: Wow how over rated can a place get? outside of the warm Thyme bread to start, the entire meal was a disappointment. From the arrogance of the chef tasting menu where they don't tell you whats on the menu yet choose 90% of the items off the menu to the overly complex combination of simple ingredients. Its obvious that Phoenix residents are so used to eating at strip malls with their chain restaurants that this place impresses them. Save your money and eat elsewhere

ycmNGuLA-3lrBemiW8XTyQ.text: Boring and ordinary decor for such a pricey place!  We are foodies, we travel around the world, yet we love to prepare our own food.  Prices beginning at $75 per person without wine for the Pre Fix menu and mandatory that EVERYONE at the table must order it in order for one person to have it, began our frustration with this place.     It took our waiter an extremely long time in between each request  of, 'a fork, water, bread, wine, each course, etc.' and our dining experience continued for 3 hours - without dessert, and it was a birthday celebration.  Entirely too long and not enough attention for the mandatory gratuity at the end.     The prices were absolutely OUT OF LINE with the food delivered. Our waiter was arrogant, seeming to know and deliver more information about why they 'don't offer whole wheat pasta as an alternative', etc. etc.     Every other food item listed on the menu was unknown by all 6 of us college-educated adutls.  This alone made it difficult to know what we would be eating and paying for.  We questioned the waiter about it all, but it makes for an uneasy feeling, not knowing if the one ingredient in our salad, or entree would change the taste to the point of not enjoying it.     In an attempt to find something I could order without meat or a cream sauce, I ordered the pasta with a request to have the cream sauce substituted with Olive Oil.  I was delivered an entirely different meal.  The waiter and or the chef decided that i should get the vegan dish instead.  I have never had this experience and it was quite unusual, so say the least.  The waiter didn't apologize, but said the chef thought i would be happier with the other dish.     We were compensated by not having to pay for this vegan dish, without having to ask, but I was not happy with this service, when I was the paying customer.     The $15 antipasta plate had 2 small triangle of cheese, 2 very thin slices of salami and a bread stick.  Really!  Everything was alacarte if you didn't do the Pri Fix.  We finally asked for bread after we had been in our chairs for 30 minutes, starving for a morsel of food that didn't have a price on it.  Customary, ESPECIALLY at any 5 start restaurant!     Too far to drive, too expensive, and NOT reflective of all the reviews and hype.       The worst part is that we were stuck having to pay an 18% gratuity regardless of the quality of our service.  This is America, where the wait staff earns tip money above 15%.  They have some work to do on their menu, their staff!, and their values.

GRCymMwwwX-HhEQJ8C3BQg.text: I am fairly new to Yelp, and the restaurant reviews, and it is more than a bit confusing. When I looked at reviews for this restaurant, I was thinking that perhaps we should not go - there were so many negative comments about the, staff and/or the food.  But we went anyway. And, I've got to tell you that the entire evening was terrific!  We chose the full 6 course dinner with wine paring.  Not only was the food fantastic, but the staff could not have been more professional, caring, and just plain terrific.   There were 8 of us for dinner, yet the kitchen turned out the food on a perfectly timed basis, and was overall an awesome evening. In the future, if I use Yelp, I will only read the positive comments, those with negative comments are probably just not too happy generally......

t4DcC6ZIXOOXoFiptG1nAA.text: I was in the restaurant last Friday. It was wonderful. This is among the best places I have eaten in Phoenix. I had the beef, almost a stew. It was very well prepared. My cousin raved about the gnocchi. My favorite thing about this place is the low key atmosphere. The wait staff is low key, attentive, but not overbearing. The house is charming and its a really comfortable place to sit and have a leisurely meal.   I would have given the restaurant five stars but I question how it can charge $48 for a bottle of Arizona wine. It was a pretty terrible bottle. I would have sent it back, but I wanted to give it a shot so ultimately it's my fault for not saying anything to the waiter. Our second bottle was a lovely California Pinot Noir.   If you haven't been to Quiessence add it to the top of your list.

843arNmrfY22PJpKGsVAGw.text: Five stars is definitely tough to give but this place gets it. The ambiance, food, and service were all amazing. For me,it is definitely a special occasion type of place. Great romantic spot, but guys I wouldn't take a crap shoot first or second date here. A dinner for two will run 200 bucks easily, especially if you do the 75 dollar a head six coarse meal, which is what we ordered and it was organic food porn heaven, every coarse. Set aside about two hours for this meal, they space it out perfectly between courses, so when that six coarse dessert hits the table I still was able to fit it in my belly and not feel disgustingly bloated and did not need a "I'm too overweight to walk scooter" when I left.

cjfa-LiXcs4qONQImIEzQA.text: This is one of my top five favorite restaurants in Phoenix. The food is made fresh by the chef with lots of natural ingredients from the farm. The atmosphere is relaxed and romantic. The food, the service, the ambiance, it's all worth the somewhat pricey food!

nFOp0ysgK5nfrSSHOHpG4g.text: I was invited here recently for an event. Having never been, I was excited, especially since they feature local AZ wines.   While there, I had a fantastic time. Paris James, their musician that night, was outstanding. I'd listen to him play every day for the rest of my life.   However, when I left and headed home, everything turned from great to oh-my-god-i-want-to-die agony.   So, I will sum up this review with two words: FOOD POISONING!

jDm2mELxE8g3jZjz0b0RbQ.text: This place does it.  This place is absolutely wonderful.  Local fresh ingredients, great atmosphere, excellent service, delicious dishes, great cheese, beer, and wine list.  If you want a really romantic dinner, and want it to last.  Go here.  Your meal will probably last 2-3 hours.  I went here with my fiance for her birthday and we loved it.  We sat outside and enjoyed a 3 course meal with drinks.  It is sort of pricey, but completely worth it.  Highly recommended.

21jC0Io7h4Eg6jsn-zu01g.text: Update: The restaurant has undergone a complete revamping of staff and menu, so the following is a review of the old establishment. I'll try the new one soon and am  praying it's still great, but it's now related to House at Secret Garden, which has taken  a serious downturn into mediocrity the last couple times I visited.   Each year I spend March in Phoenix, and I've long wanted to try Quiessence. This year I stayed at the Legacy Golf Resort just next door to the Farm . . .so I had no excuse, and I have not been disappointed.  After reading several reviews here, I decided to wait until I'd visited a few times to offer my opinions. I must say that the experience, from food to service to creativity and ambiance, have been spectacular.  I now have had four meals at Quiessence, and the staff has made me feel very much at home. Each time I've had the vegetable plate 'From the Ground,' and each time it's been a different combination of flavors and textures straight from the garden, plated beautifully to the point of taking out the IPhone for a photo before devouring. The pasta dishes are worth pointing out...they change almost daily, and they've always been creative and delicious. Also, don't shy from the duck egg preparations. Last week an egg-en-cocotte was divine, and last night's soft scrambled duck egg with black truffles was plate-lickingly good.  The staff has shockingly turned me on to Arizona wines, something I would never have ventured into blindly. The Sand Reckoner 7 was so good that I found some at a local store to take East with me to offer up as a ringer in an upcoming blind syrah tasting in New Jersey. Call in advance to secure a table in the main room or outside...the back room is not nearly as romantic. Once I sat alone at the community table overlooking the bar, which was fine for that occasion, as I got to know another couple and we had a delightful time together. Yes, it's expensive, and if you're looking for a slab of grilled meat or chunk of lasagna, don't waste your time or money. But if you appreciate a singularly romantic setting, perfect service, culinary creativity and fresh preparation, you won't be disappointed. Each visit has brought a smile to my face and a yearning to return.

T_CqdWhAawWMY1B_DjEx0w.text: My husband and I came to Quiessence for dinner before they closed for the summer. We learned about it from the Pulling Corks and Forks blog and are so glad we did!  The dinner was so memorable and delicious. They staff is very attentive and accommodating to dietary restrictions -- I'm a vegetarian and my husband has celiacs disease. After dinner we explored the picturesque grounds and saw their chickens and tortoise. So cute!

photos.caption: Photo of Quiessence At The Farm - Phoenix, AZ, United States

5C_R0i6hidvlvL7FhRgSFA.text: Meh! Our experience was memorable.... BUT NOT in a good way. We arrived early. There were plenty of tables but were not allowed to be seated. I know there is timing in the kitchen, but, we just wanted to have a cocktail. So, we sat by a fire and waited probably 15 minutes for drink service which I asked for twice. The menu was limited to a tasting menu. Which was fine except every choice had meat. We  asked for vegetarian/fish options which were accommodated.    We ordered the  Rose , which came out fizzy. And the server tried to defend the fizz. This was not a sparkling wine. It was returned and taken off the bill.The courses were very small, with long stretches of time in between. I figured it was punishment for the fizzy wine return.The fish was good but came out tepid and about 30 minutes after the last dish. The black eyed peas and poached tomatoes under the fish were gross and bitter. The wait staff forgot what was in the dish while they were describing it. The cannoli dessert was fair. But, you better like apples. I think the restaurant is pretentious and dependent on the atmosphere. I have lived here for 45 years and can think of way better places to spend that kind of money. This is not the first time that similar things have happened. We were hoping that it was an off night. Now we see it's an unfortunate pattern.  Last night was the last night!

DP5UopBzS2NG7Fa9Mnd0Ww.text: Once we found it (be sure you're on 32nd), it was AMAZING! The grounds are spectacularly lit; we will be back to explore when it's not raining. The food was exquisite! My best meal of 2019!!! Flavors are superb; presentation was spectacular; service was attentive but not intrusive. AZ wine was a red blend & complemented the food; cannoli was AWESOME as were the lemon verbena & watermelon sorbets. WOW! And quite reasonably priced..,

photos.caption: Photo of Quiessence At The Farm - Phoenix, AZ, United States
Photo of Quiessence At The Farm - Phoenix, AZ, United States. Maya&#39;s Foraged Garden Maya&#39;s Foraged Garden

snQSdnSftLNdCdoqe6bb6w.text: We had a four-course Valentine's Day dinner here with wine pairings, resulting in a 3 hour dining experience.  It was incredible!  I'm floored by the mediocre reviews.  Quissence is an intimate, unique space with attentive service and delicious meals.  Let's start with the positives.    1) Ambiance: we made a reservation for 8:15 PM and were seated quickly.  Neither the indoor nor outdoor area were overcrowded, providing for a peaceful dinner. 2) Food: fresh, farm-to-table yet upscale dining experience.  Seriously, made from scratch, balanced courses that are beautifully plated.  (Highly recommended: pistachio soup, both the duck and trout, and the bread pudding)  3) Added touches for the special day: multiple complimentary baskets of focaccia, red sparkling wine at the start of the meal, a heart shaped waffle appetizer, and blood orange macaroons at the end.  We loved the small surprises throughout the meal.  10/10 would dine again.  One negative: It'll put a pretty big dent in the wallet (comparatively to other similar dining experiences) so save for SPECIAL occasions.

photos.caption: Photo of Quiessence At The Farm - Phoenix, AZ, United States. Crispy skin steelhead trout.

ifv4l2yoFVT7MybEV-Rp3Q.text: Amazing food, terrific ambience, efficient service and again fabulous food.   Yes the restaurant is pricey, however, the quality of food, the thought process in bringing ingredients together to make a successful plate is well worth the hole in the wallet.   The desserts are to die for...

photos.caption: Photo of Quiessence At The Farm - Phoenix, AZ, United States
Photo of Quiessence At The Farm - Phoenix, AZ, United States. Cannoli with green Apple sorbet! Best dessert to order imo
Photo of Quiessence At The Farm - Phoenix, AZ, United States

DdQ80vnjA68m_RaJZL9Cyw.text: We had a very well prepared meal while at this restaurant. We both ordered the chefs choice 6 item wine pairing dinners and the items served were excellent. The ambience is quite nice and the seating gives a great view.  The only problem that I noticed was in the serving of the courses.  The waiter that brought the items spoke so softly that most of the time I had no idea what he brought out. The second thing was the wine pairing. In six courses the only red wine served was on the fourth course with the duck confit. Then it was back to whites. First time I have gone from red wine to white as the meal progressed. Lastly, it was that the wine pairings came out far to long after the food was served. In one or two instances the food was just a bite and the wine came out 10 minutes afterwards. That needs to be fixed.  Overall, the Restraunt deserves a 4 in my book.

bC-WMBRQ81BxhfcgshQaXQ.text: Stellar dining experience! Exceptional service, food, and facilities. Expect a leisurely dinner with lots of time for drinks and conversation.   We went with a group of 12 on a Wednesday evening. It was a leisurely meal that started with handcrafted cocktails and an array of starters. The restaurant offers 5 and 6 course dinners with wine pairing, but our table opted the share a number of starters and order off the menu. The menu changes depending on the ingredients available.   The Artisan bread basket was delicious and the herbs and balsamic made each bite special. The Meat Shop pork belly was out of this world. It does come with peanuts so beware if anyone at your table has a food allergy.  The Aged beef carpaccio had excellent flavor.   I had the Kohlrabi soup with poached egg. The egg was perfectly cooked. The chicken stock was a little bland and could have used a touch if salt (a universal comment at our table). The people who ordered salads were thrilled with their plates.   For the main course, some ordered scallops and steak, while others opted for pasta dishes. I had the potato gnocchi, which was divine. The gnocchi were soft and delicious! I also tried a scallop and it was quite delicious, as was the aged New York strip.   Dessert did not disappoint. I ate a delicious bread pudding. The churro dessert was beautifully presented and fully eaten by everyone who ordered it. The sherbet was plated splendidly and was enjoyed.

photos.caption: Photo of Quiessence At The Farm - Phoenix, AZ, United States
Photo of Quiessence At The Farm - Phoenix, AZ, United States. Bread basket
Photo of Quiessence At The Farm - Phoenix, AZ, United States

W-x_U903dBx5mbvGwcwjPA.text: Wonderful experience! Very charming, romantic restaurant and beautiful at night. Service was excellent and knowledgeable. The food was delicious and the portion sizes were perfect. Started with the pork belly board that was amazing. The pork belly and honey were a perfect pair together. Then the Parmesan soup with roasted artichokes was smooth and delicious. Final the main course was the aged New York strip, loved it. I would definitely recommend!

photos.caption: Photo of Quiessence At The Farm - Phoenix, AZ, United States. Lemon Verbana Melontini
Photo of Quiessence At The Farm - Phoenix, AZ, United States. The Meat Shop Pork Belly!! (5 Stars)
Photo of Quiessence At The Farm - Phoenix, AZ, United States. Aged New York Strip

LS3b6iyiR7Qw4ErfvzD2Ow.text: 3.5 stars. This is a very unique experience, potentially one of the most unique to be found in Phoenix area. The farm fresh produce, the ambiance of a little farm house and tons of bunnies running around invokes a sense of hunger that is guaranteed to result in a very substantial bill. The meal was tasty and menu rotates all the time. A couple dishes were a little heavy on the salt, but otherwise were some creative and interesting combinations that were very enjoyable. Some other things about this place do not correspond to the prices, thus I suspect is the reason for lower than expected yelp ratings. For example, they pour beers into the kind of glasses one would find at a pub or on a shelf of a dollar general. Even the beers that should have proper glassware for the style. There is a time and a place for everything, but surely not at an establishment where one is spending $$$$ on a meal.  The interior of the house with terra-cotta tiles is very basic, also a bit boring I'd say. The middle room is the worst, there is no design and it felt like the interior was slapped together by whatever furniture and materials were laying around "the farm". The interior design, or lack of it, does take away from the experience. It is cheap, while the menu is not at all. Perhaps some will find the charm in the house being untouched, so it may be a matter of preference. If the weather allows and they have it open, I'd recommend outdoor seating instead.  After dinner, walking through the grounds is a must. Surrounded by large trees, there is a feeling that you are no longer in the desert and there is a sense of being in a magical forest. It is a spot for romantics. I could see spending an evening here painting and finishing it wish a wonderful meal.

PVOZDXjFYydrBxUyBE7-Ww.text: Our meal at Quiessence was one of the best we have ever had. Our service was great, the 6 course tasting menu was full of delicious, sometimes adventurous flavors, and the restaurant sits on a beautiful, huge property that doubles as a wedding venue. We could hear a DJ next door from our table, but it wasn't overly bothersome.  To get the full experience of the tasting menu and wine pairings, you will spend a pretty penny. However, every dish is beautiful, and you can really sense the amount of work and attention to detail that went into each course. The wine pairings were also spot on.   Being November, the outdoor seating got chilly, but they gladly moved us inside when we asked.   Overall, our dinner lasted about 3 hours, and we enjoyed it all immensely. Definitely a meal I will remember.

34EMOiYAro23mSx4kfYuLQ.text: Six course tasting menu was playful and (most importantly) delicious. Beautiful location and great service. Wonderful way to celebrate our anniversary.

z2Izia1jOMW-mm6rGhfKuA.text: Visited in March and this by far is the best dining experience I've ever had. From service to food quality: 5-stars.

fT-RYkuC54qyx54cczc7_A.text: For the price Quiessence did not meet our expectations.  When you pay $500+ for dinner, I expect exceptional food, exceptional service, and exceptional environment.  We spent about 3 1/2 hours at the restaurant the other evening; which we were expecting.  The problem with that is that we were seated in the sunroom area, which had very little airflow, and was EXTREMELY hot.  My husband and myself had to fan ourselves the entire dinner.  I understand it is an older building, but if we had been warned prior to our reservations that the main "house" dining area was not available, we would have rescheduled our reservations for another date.  Our server was very friendly, and knew the menu.  We chose the six-course tasting menu with wine pairing addition.  Our courses were mixed up midway through as well as the wine pairing; (we received meals in the incorrect order, and incorrect wine pairing with the meals).  Overall the taste of the food was ok; for us, not worth an almost $600 meal.

KuYxbbRzTyakbJ3StfL8gw.text: One of the finest meals I've had. We came for our anniversary and both had the tasting menu and loved each course. Service was attentive and helpful. We'll definitely be back again.

78kXwJVnqkaS3EAdJdMW3w.text: I attended a dinner here for an event and the food was good, not great but service was friendly and punctual.    We returned for my birthday dinner with a gift card we had from our wedding. The gift card had expired by one year which I had no idea because who really creates gift cards with expiration dates anymore. We noticed as our Uber picked us up and decided to make the 20 minute Uber ride anyway thinking maybe they would deduct money.    Long story short they did not honor any of the $200 gift card. WOW so we asked "basically our friends donated $200 here?" And they said yes unfortunately that's their policy.  Really poor experience as this was my birthday dinner. Will not try to return here.

MkMs7RxvxUqSWoaIh5A7sw.text: Make Quiessence a night to remember. Located on a lovely farm close to the airport this tucked away restaurant features fresh, skillfully prepared plates of delicious food.   Our party of 7 enjoyed appetizers of carefully prepared chef's board, cauliflower with lamb heart, beet salad with blue cheese, foraged mixed vegetables and raw kampachi on a salt block. For dinner our table ordered the aged New York strip cooked to order, the sturgeon and the crisp house made gnocchi. To finish the evening we got one dessert and it was the their wonderful bread pudding with vanilla ice cream. Any description does not do the food justice so I will leave it at that.   The drinks were equally as delicious. Their margarita was the best margarita I have ever had. The wine was carefully selected and very much pleased the wine drinkers at the table.   Each dish was prepared and presented with care and every bite was harmoniously balanced both in flavor and in texture. It was, in a word, exquisite.   Our waiter, Robby, was friendly, knowledgeable and had great wine recommendations.  Good food with fresh ingredients takes time so be prepared to have your meal last a couple (or four) hours. Although, I found it refreshing to spend time catching up with old and new friends.   Quiessence is a restaurant where quality outweighs quantity. While portions are European and prices are high, the food is absolutely worth every penny.   So sit back, enjoy the night and let your taste buds enjoy a delightful meal.

photos.caption: Photo of Quiessence At The Farm - Phoenix, AZ, United States. Margarita.
Photo of Quiessence At The Farm - Phoenix, AZ, United States. Kampachi Crudo.

-Jv5CRTHBU-LQhyPd07edQ.text: Atmosphere A+++ Service A Food B Prices C  I enjoy a nice meal in a nice restaurant and don't think twice about paying a bit extra.  This time I have to agree with many of the other reviews.    While it was an enjoyable evening I can only give it three stars because of small portions vs price.

photos.caption: Photo of Quiessence At The Farm - Phoenix, AZ, United States. Bathroom
Photo of Quiessence At The Farm - Phoenix, AZ, United States. Califlower Soup with shrimp

eMtUj2lRkLOosdQZXixTPQ.text: My first visit and I will say from todays experince this place is a must try! From our service, to the ambience and the incredible scratch menu nothing went wrong. Being there on a  Sunday for brunch there was a wait, but the staff directed you to a choice of many drinks that were self  service while you wait. Coffee, OJ and water- they even had mimosas waiting for those interested.   On a side note, you will be so lucky if you get Barbie as your server! She rocks it and makes a mean bloody mary!   All and all with the beautiful surroundings and fresh food I would recommend this to everyone!

tQNJFmi34oB_E8_c66k8FA.text: Celebrating a couple late birthdays brought us to this quaint little restaurant tucked away at the back of The Farm at South Mountain. I've been to a few weddings here but last night was the first time to actually dine at Quiessence Restaurant. It's an interesting name because the word "quiescence" refers to a period of dormancy or inactivity, so I'm not sure if the names have anything in common or just coincidence.   This restaurant is anything but dormant. It is warm, inviting, and perhaps even romantic if you wish it to be. The Saltillo tile floors add depth to this home and we were seated right next to the original door and fireplace of this historic abode.   The 6 course tasting menu with the wine pairings allowed the four of us to fully indulge in the experience at The Farm. The 2 1/2 hour experience allowed us to get plenty of conversation in along with giving us time to digest between courses. We almost couldn't keep up with all the wine pairings since there was such food variety brought before us. With the chef selection, we did not all receive the same menu items so we were able to sample a bit of everything the menu had to offer!   Chef's Board - our favorite diversion! Pineapple crisps wedged into rich goat cheese, persimmon fruit roll ups, pate, stuffed olives, onion slices stabbing mustard seeds, wavy round thin pork slices with homemade jam - the varying textures and combinations of flavors was a treat   Shrimp soup - simple battered Mexican shrimp bathed in a creamy soup. The shrimp was large and dense but in a good way  Beef carpaccio- just as described but served on unique thin toast that was curled not tough like biscotti but perfectly done toast. Really liked this one!  Cavaletti pasta - rich and served with what I think was tender beef (it was a little hard to hear our waitress due to the table next to us being a little loud). You really can't go wrong with pasta and meat..  Steelhead trout (what I had) OR Aged New York Strip in Chimchurri.   The trout was delicate but had the density and color of salmon since it was wild steelhead trout. Served with a potato creme fraische.  The New York Strip was cooked to perfection and definitely was paired well with the chimchurri sauce.  Bread pudding with vanilla ice cream OR panna cotta? - since the steelhead was a lighter entree, the bread pudding followed it. It was phenomenal! My favorite part of all 6 courses. The steak was followed by the panna dessert which was good but the bread pudding was waaaaaay better.

photos.caption: Photo of Quiessence At The Farm - Phoenix, AZ, United States. Bread pudding with vanilla ice cream
Photo of Quiessence At The Farm - Phoenix, AZ, United States. Dessert!
Photo of Quiessence At The Farm - Phoenix, AZ, United States. Ribeye strip with chimchurri sauce

i33-CYFvTTH_VyYhc9uOKA.text: Excellent dining. The farm and night is best. The food at the restaurant is exquisite, all home grown. They take their time on each course and it was fabulous knowing that they are not in a hurry. My husband and I were celebrating our Anniversary and we chose the 5-course dinner. My husband pair each course with a different wine. Each wine was perfect!!!! The staff was very friendly. We truly recommend this beautiful place.
